reviewText:
Note: My play time on Steam is NOT what I determined this review with. I played before it came to Steam.


First off my guild(The Oran'Thul) was personally contacted by the devs of Echo of Soul to test the game. This is an unbiased, truthful review of the game.



Let me start by saying I plan to give this game a negative review. Now that's not saying its terrible and its not worth playing, but for those who take their MMOs seriously and competitively, you are going to want to steer clear of this one.


Echo of Soul at its core is a pretty decent MMO, entertaining pve and pvp. It does not stand out from the rest of the MMO's but for the features it does have, it does do them pretty well.

The MAJOR issues that this game suffers from is pretty much what plagues every other MMO that has been released for the past few years.

1. PAY TO WIN.

This is a MAJOR issue for those who wish to play MMOs competitively and take their MMOs seriously. This game comes from Aeria games, for those of you who have played their games before you most likely are not surprised to hear that this game is P2W.

2. BALANCE ISSUES.

My god.....my guild and I looked past the pay to win issue in this game and said meh its an MMO to kill time with". When we got into the battlegrounds....  the balance...MY GOD THE BALANCE!!!!

The issue became apparent when we were sitll low levels
date: so we brushed it off as a balance issue at lower level pvp. As we leveled the issue became much...MUCH worse.\n\nThere are currently 5 classes in the game
recommended: 3 are nearly unplayable vs the other 2. Can you guess who the underpowered ones are? As always
hoursPlayed:
its the melee. The sorceress and the Archer are disgustingly overpowered to the point that you shouldn't even bother pvping at all as a melee.

3. CHANNEL SYSTEM

The channel system...the bane on all open world MMOs. For those of you who dont know what a channel system is....here is a quick explanation.

A channel system is pretty much a way to take one server and break it up into a ton of mini servers. This allows the developers to spread out a congested world so players arent overcrowding everything to the point that there are no mobs to kill and you cant move an inch without being ganked.

There is a right way
voteText: and a wrong way to implement a system like this. Echo of Soul does it the wrong way.\n\nAs you progress through the game you are constantly entering little instance portals
helpfulPercent: this hurts the game as you get the feeling that the world is not an open worlds
votesHelpful:
its just a bunch of mini instances smashed together with load screens between each of them.

When you enter these portals you are thrown into a random channel of that specific zone.

For instance...

FOREST ZONE (CHANNEL 2) --> CAVE ZONE (CHANNEL 4)

As you can see above
votesTotal: when you progress from one zone to another you are thrown into a random channel. This may be packed full of players
votesFunny: or have none at all.\n\nThis really destroys the feeling of being in an open
commentsCount:
growing world filled with players.

In addition this absolutely KILLS world pvp. My guild and I found it nearly impossible to join a friend in a channel to participate in world pvp becuase the channel was filled.

Lastely this also allows players to leave the channel to run away from potential pvp.

This truly makes for a babies MMO and anyone serious about their MMOs should stay away.

EXP AND GOLD GAIN DOUBLED FOR 24 HOURS.

Appraisers Pouch = Reroll stats on a piece of gear to obtain the one that suits you best.

AND THE WORST MOST PAY TO WIN CRAP IN THE GAME

SAFEGUARD = PREVENTS A JEWEL FROM BEING DESTROYED WHEN ENHANCEMENT FAILS. - This right here.

And in Addition...
ENHANCEMENT BOOSTER = INCREASE THE CHANCE FOR A SUCCESFULL ENHANCEMENT.

Jewels are single BEST way to increase your gear. You know those MMOs where you can increase a piece of gear from +1 to +5 without failing then anything from +6 to +9 has a chance to downgrade then anything above +9 has a chance to break the piece of gear?

Well these jewels are that in a nutshell. A player with +10 gems in every slot can easily kill 5 players at the same time if those players have no gems.

If you continue to use this item and shovel heaps and heaps of money into the cash shop. YOU. WILL. BECOME. A. GOD.

It may take you $1000

reviewText:
I would like to start by saying I havn't tried the PvP side of the game and doubt i will, its just not my thing so I will leave that for people that play that way to comment on that side of things, so that said i will comment on the PVE side which is the way I play my main MMo's (WoW, FFXI, FFXIV and Rift).

I've found this nice fun, easy to play and learn, although im not through to end game content yet Im still questing through and leveling my mage I am finding it nicely paced and not too rushed. If you play other mmo's ou'll find the quests are of the usual variety collect X of this, kill Y of those monsters, one feature i do like and wish a few others would pick up and incorperate into thier games is that not only do the quests show on the mini map each quest has a little arrow and distance marker beside it showing where to go and how far it is, nice touch thanks, quest text is clear and easily readable and understandable and also conveys the game lore without it being bashed over your head with it.
The single player dungeons are also a nice touch aswell, it gives you  the chance run off do a dungeon without having to hang around either waiting for a group finder to get a group for you or you tring to PUG a group, the instances are not insainely difficault and can be done with quest dropped items and also give good rewards without spending ages to finish   there are some simple tactics to each boss which are easy to pick up and learn, and the usual rule applies Dont stand in the Fire".
To the big question being as it is free to play is it pay to win?   As far as PVE goes not really
date:
you can get boosts and safegaurds to your crafting and things of that fayre but most of the pay for items I've seen so far are vanaty Items and these can be perchased in game from merchants with gold and silver anyway.

Conclusion...
Would i recommend this game to other people? Yes
recommended: it makes an ideal starter MMo for people comming into the genre its not overly complicated and everything is explained for you
hoursPlayed: its not as "grindy" as some i could mention and has a nice pace to it. It does not have the cutting edge graphics that some of the latest MMo's have so can be played on an average  PC or Laptop which is no bad thing
voteText: not everyone can afford a top end gaming rig. For an experienced MMo player like myself i found it a nice change
helpfulPercent: everone one i've spoken to in game has been friendly and helpfull which is nice and bodes well for the in game community as a whole. While this will never replace my main MMo's its also not going to be left out either."

reviewText:
I definitely recommend this game!

As a ex-hardcore wow player, I would like to share my thoughts on this game as well.

I played this game as a rogue through CBT and the OBT!

Let me give you an honest feedback about this game

1. Creating a character is a little bit weird since you have  gender locked  classes.
Beside that: The options to customize your character are really nice! I'm very happy with the way my char looks!

2. Graphics: The game will not deliver the best graphics in history but its decent for a f2p. Not everybody can afford to have a BiS computer. It can reach a wider audience and attracts more players.

3. First Steps: The game basically supports you in every possible way.  Quests to introduce the dungeon browser, pvp browser and so on.

4. Questing: Of course its the usual Search X and deliver it to Y, Kill X amount of Y but there are other quests as well. I'm not positively surprised but also not disappointed.

5. PvP: You can clearly feel, that the game is made for Characters who reached level 60. You can join the pvp battle as soon as you hit level 10 (with an outstanding matchmaking system) and you most likely get owned by people who have a higher level than you. You resistance and HP are pumped up to level 60 standard but you can obviously not compete with your level 10 gear and skillset. Nevertheless, I was able to get the mvp (best player in the team) a lot of times when i was between level 10 and 40. The PvP is not necessarily innovative but it gives a ton of xp, and is really fun. Even though you are a melee and not level 60.

I also dont get why people complain about (always the same). They took the best content of other games and implemented it here. Its a nice combination of my favourite MMOS.

6. PvE: I really really like the Single Dungeon System and the grouping is amazing as well. You can match groups or go alone. One criticism: The leader can just kick people for whatever reason. If you dont have the super awesome gear, you get kicked in most of the times. On the other hand: It helps a lot to not wipe infinitely and if you dont have good gear, get some. There are tons of ways to farm good stuff in the game and i dont speak about cashing in.

7. p2w?: Yes and No! Of course, this is a f2p title and some paid features give you some kind of advantage. I think, Aeria wants to make things different here and when I compare this Launch to Aura Kingdom back in the days, I can clearly say, that this here is totally different.

I never had the feeling that I have to spend money. Questing was always flawless, never an artificial blocker which annoyed me or forced me to buy an xp boost. There are tons of free events which give me some nice goodies.

Im pretty okay with the fact that people who spend money get some benefits since they are keeping the service alive!

Summary:

There are pros and cons but eventually the game is a lot of fun to play, even without paying!

The game is not really free". Paying users get some benefits but they dont have an impact on the fairness in game. You can achieve everything without paying in a reasonable time. Its just like a p2p mmo but paying users get a small advantage. Pretty fair imo."

reviewText:
How to begin with Echo of Soul...

I suppose to begin, I'm gong to give my rating on this game:  8/10 (reserving judgment due to the status of the game being Open Beta) => RECOMMENDED

I've had a bit of a love-hate relationship with Aeria Games since I first became a member in 2008.  Echo of Soul is the third of their published games which I've played for more than 2 days.  In fact, I've been playing this game since their Open Beta launch on June 1st.  But this isn't about my history with others of Aeria's games, this review is about this one in particular.  Let's begin, shall we?

=====CHARACTER CREATION=====
The first thing you'll notice about Echo of Soul is that there are a total of five classes (thus far) to choose from.  These classes are gender-locked, and each class has two spec mastery paths.  The gender lock is there to follow with the game's storyline.  The classes you can choose from are as follows:

1.  Male Warrior
2.  Male Rogue
3.  Female Guardian (Lancer, for those familiar with Tera)
4.  Female Mage
5.  Female Archer

As you will begin to notice, there is no dedicated healing class.  More on this later.

Each class has different customization options available to further make your character unique in physical appearance.  You then start off with a default costume (I can assume this to be random from a small pool, as I've created different characters of the same class, and ended up with differing clothing looks from the get-go.)

=====LEVELING=====
Leveling in Echo of Soul is very much geared toward the casual player.  For the hardcore speedlevelers, it's possible to make it from levels 1 to 60 (current cap, at time of review) in a matter of 1-3 days through the game's PvP Battlegrounds (accessible starting at level 10.)  For the more casual player, you can still make it to 60 relatively quickly or you can take your time with it.  Moderate-speed casual players can make it inside of a week.  Slow casuals can make it to cap in abotu 2 weeks of gameplay time.

Both PvP and PvE Questing offer a very generous amount of EXP, so reaching cap is entirely on how you want to do it.  You can go solely as a Battlegrounds resident, through the PvE story, or mix it up a bit.  For the best leveling experience, I would recommend doing either PvP or PvE (depending on which one you want to stick to primarily) just to try it out.

Grinding mobs in the overworld will provide very little in the way of EXP.  Grinding overworld mobs is an easy option to obtain enhancement jewels, crafting ingredients, or even some crafting recipes.  If you wish to do PvE grind for EXP, then your best bet would be to do so in the dungeons.  Though, grinding out the dungeons might not be a bad idea, as the sub and main bosses can provide your character with class-specific equipment sets to further enhance your stats and abilities.  There is also the option to take repeatables in maps called Infinite Hunting Grounds which also reward a fair amount of EXP per turn-in.

=====ECONOMY=====
There are a couple of things which new players will find out relatively quickly:
1.  Mobs do not drop money.
2.  Items from NPC vendors are really cheap.

This means it will be relatively difficult to make solid gold before your 50-60 level bracket.  I would assume it to be a tactic by the developers to maintain a relatively strong pre-endgame economy.  With that being said, there is no restrictions on the amount of in-game gold you can carry in difference to those at level cap.  If you wish to make some quick major gold for your earlier levels, your best bet would be to utilize the cash shop and in-game auction board.

As I have not hit level cap, as of yet (I'm a -very- slow player, and have taken more time to get to know the forum community due to my work/sleep schedules) I will not post a comment on endgame economy.

=====QUESTING=====
PvE questing is quite linear, and very story-based.  While you do get a vast amount of miscellaneous quests (both overworld and dungeon) the magic of PvE questing truly shines with the story-based quests.  As with most typical MMORPGs, you get EXP, money, and the occasional piece of gear to upgrade your set.  However, it's also relatively easy to outlevel some of these quests, but the EXP you gain from some of the lower-level quests is still quite generous.

=====Player-versus-Player=====
Echo of Soul offers two types of PvP:  Battlegrounds and Open-World Guild vs Guild.  Let's expand, shall we?

Currently, there are two Battlegrounds maps (both accessible starting at level 10.)  Both are points-based Capture the Flag-esque types.  One requires teams to capture resources spawned on the map, and the other requires teams to capture and hold towers for as long as possible.  The actual player-kill aspect of these battlegrounds can be quite hectic and fast-paced.  There are also two tiers of Battlegrounds- one for Levels 10-59, and one exclusively for Level 60.

Open-World GvG takes place between guilds which have declared themselves to be hostile.  Players in hostile guilds are fair game to be PK'd at any time, anywhere by other hostile guilds' members.  Guildless and Peaceful-alligned guild players do not have to worry about being randomly PK'd while running around the overworld maps.

There is also a PvP event (run at least daily) called Valhalla.  Since I have yet to participate in this event, I cannot write a review about it.

=====CRAFTING=====
Like the rest of the game, crafting is geared toward the more casual player.  Relatively cheap and brainless, it's fairly easy to level both a profession and the two hobby crafting skills available in a short amount of time.  Certain tiers of crafting require certain character levels to be obtained.  Beginner-level crafters can gain most of their supplies directly from their crafting vendor.  However, there does come a time where some mob grinding is required to get higher level base materials.

=====UNIQUE FEATURES=====
1.  Echo of Soul has a hunger system.  This is determined by two values:  Energy and Satiety.  The higher your current energy level is to your max, certain buffs are applied to your character.  You increase energy by eating foods which are crafted or obtained as quest rewards.  Satiety is how much food you can eat.  With a max value of 1,000 and each piece of food taking up 200 Satiety, this leaves you with a maximum of 5 food waten at a time.  Satiety can be decreased over time, or with the use of a Digestant item.  Energy is depleted through the use of skills.

2.  The Soul System:  Through daily rewards or killing of mobs, you can obtain what's called Chaos Souls."  When purified (either near a purification point
date: or cooperatively with another player) these souls can grant you charges for temporary buffs.\n\n3.  The Cash Shop:  While most free-to-play MMOs out there have a cash shop which is mostly geared to be pay-to-win
recommended: Echo of Souls isn't geared that way.  Mostly asthetics or RNG fun
hoursPlayed: there is literally nothing on the cash shop which you are required to get to advance in the game
voteText:
or gain a significant advantage.  The things on the shop which seem that way are literally a pay-to-be-lazy mechanic.

4.  No Dedicated Healer Class:  The entire party works as a team to heal!

=====THE BADS=====
1.  There is no general server chat channel.  Primary communication is done at either close-range
helpfulPercent: through the use of the Loudspeaker items
votesHelpful: or on the map-specific Shout channel.  Unless you get yourself into an active guild
votesTotal: or are part of a different chat system (i.e. Teamspeak) prepare to be playing mostly in blisful chat silence towards you.\n\n2.  Your other Typicals:  Elitists
votesFunny: gold spammers
commentsCount:
and general complaining doomsday naysayers.

=====TL;DR=====
If you're a casual gamer looking for a casual game which you can level relatively easily without getting too far behind the curve
column16: then Echo of Soul is a good pick for you!"

reviewText:
So Echo of Soul will be my first Review :)

Let's start it off with the basics:

Classes: There are 5 classes with 2 (3) different roles. There are tanks (Protector and Earthguard), DDs ( Rogue, Mage, Hunter, Berseker and Stormguard) and Supporter (Bard). Yes there is no healer, which gives you the control of your own healthbar.

Professions: Haven't looked in to it too much till now but there are primary (resource gathering, alchemy, juwelery) and secondary (soul something and cooking) professions)

Control: You use your mouse to target things and move your camera. Your keyboard is for interacting with npcs and using skills. So nothing out of the odinary.

Leveling: Leveling is quite easy. You can quick select quests with f, you have a build in questhelper and the first 20-30 Lvls are easily done. The longer you are in the game, the more you must be casious about your skills and need to find a good rotation to progress quickly.

Combat: It's a rotation and static based combat system. You cant move while attacking/casting. That being said, the Fights with bosses relies on heavy movement mechanics, which makes things really difficult sometimes. I like that system, it leaves it to you to optimize your dmg output.

PvP: 2 PVP maps, 5v5 Arena and Guildbattles at the start of a F2P game? Check! that's actually pretty big and well done.

Dungeons: You have lots of solo dungeons (every 10 lvls 1) which gives you the opportunity to equip yourself and have some fun thorugh the leveling process. There are group dungeons too, but mostly for lvl 60 chars.

Endgame: This Game has it all: good balanced pvp (no dimishing return right now, i hope they patch that in), lots of dungeon content, tiered equip, lots of dailys and professions to do. It won't get boring!

Difficulty: I would say you can compare it easily to Vanilla wow, which was for me the most challenging mmo experience I had so far. Most bosses punishing mistakes quite heavily and you won't get much help through guides because there aren't many out yet. You need to learn everything for yourself and that in an environment which is not forgiving to mistakes. For me it's pretty fun :)

New things? when you are ahead in lvl, you can warp yourself to a higher map without the need to walk.

Bad things? For not so talented MMO player its pretty hard, very difficult to equip yourself without help in the first tiers. You can be held in Stunlock in PVP forever. Your bags are to small. All the cool looking stuff cost (normal armor looks a bit ♥♥♥♥♥♥)

Overall: I would recommend trying it out. When you get past the early 2-3 hours (pls don't hear on reviews from people with such short duration of play. They have no experience and just hate for no reason). It isn't for everyone, but it's F2P so trying it out would be the best choice for you.

reviewText:
Stopped playing after I reached level 20. It's not a bad game but it's nothing but go kill 3-5 of those monsters"and "go collect 3-5 of this plant" back-to-back non-stop. The game makes you think you're not grinding monsters like crazy by giving you low quantity kill/collect requirements per quest. But once I got an achievement for completing a 100 quests I realized I've been doing nothing but killing and collecting stuff. >_>

reviewText:
If I could give sort of a mixed opinion about this game, I would. It's one thing to say this game is bad, but it's not that great either.

For the most part, Echo of Soul plays out like your average tab-target MMO where you go around questing, leveling, etc. What separates this game from its other competitors is its focus on its endgame content, which happens at level 60. The entry barrier for getting to 60 is pretty low and you'll find the path to leveling is pretty simple. However, the moment you hit 60, you'll feel like you're starting at level 1 again. You have to grind your way up the gear ladder just to be able to run party dungeons efficiently, and PVP is not exactly a good option entering level 60 due to a number of powerful players.

This is all due to the game's inherent jewel system. The idea of jewels was pretty neat when you're introduced to it around level 15. These jewels enhance your stats and can be combined to form stronger jewels, which can be inserted into sockets on your equipment. While the jewels had a chance to break after a certain point, the game gave you a decent amount of jewels as you leveled, so there was always a steady form of progression in the form of jewels and gear. However, this was all thrown out the window and slows to a halt at level 60, mainly due to the game's separation of jewels into two tiers: dull (used from levels 1-59) and lucid (used at level 60). A fresh player will enter level 60 feeling much weaker than before, as the enemies' power suddenly spikes up as you're forced to trudge through this initial stage of endgame and progression slows down considerably.

The biggest problem here is time. As you play, you WILL get everything you need, but that depends on how much time you're willing to invest. Without friends or a nice guild helping you out, you're pretty much stuck grinding some boring dungeons until you can get more these lucid jewels for upgrading your character. The cash shop has a few time-savers that more serious players would consider investing into, from safeguards to prevent jewels from breaking when upgrading and pets that can loot items for you. I do recommend trying to play without spending on these premium items, as they're pretty unnecessary if you can play smart and try to be as self-sufficient as possible.

Other than my personal gripe with lucid jewels and the beginning of level 60, the PVE gameplay is pretty good. Questing from 1-59 was a breeze for me and once I managed to gather up some gear at level 60, the party dungeons have been fun to run through thanks to the dungeon mechanics keeping players in check. PVP from 1-59 can be pretty fun and has normalized stats to keep it in check, but I suggest staying away from level 60 PVP unless you manage to gather a lot of lucid jewels.

If you're looking for a decent F2P MMO like WoW, EoS might be a good game to check out, but I wouldn't recommend it to everyone.

reviewText:
Rewrote the review, and changed the rating.

First off, this game makes...not always sense.

For example, make an egg in this game, all you need is seasoning (which magically turns into an egg apparently)

To make a hamburger, all you need is bread. You know what my favourite kind of hamburger is? The one without any kind of meat, or lettuce, or sauce, JUST bread. Yummy.

Not to mention you can make three kinds of burgers (BBQ, Bacon ...) and they all need only one ingredient - bread.

As a person who loves crafting this is bad. You know what else is bad? Get this:

There are three professions in this game, of which you can only learn one, and two hobbies of which you can learn both.

Two of the professions need resources you can gather in the wild. Guess what the third profession is. Yep, its Resource gathering.

So either you become a resource gatherer and can make nothing out of it but sell things, or you become an alchemist or jeweler and can make nothing because you can't gather resources. If they want to create an active, living market, this is NOT the way to do it, and it somewhat cancels out a certain type of freedom, too, if you want to gather and make your own stuff out of it.

However, after playing a bit I have to say that, otherwise, the game is quite solid. The fighting is fun, the graphics are slightly above average but are used well, the game feels fluid despite using the good old tab targeting fighting system, and it constantly rewards you and keeps you engaged. It is still somewhat generic, but I rate games based on how fun they are, and...well, I am having fun.

How long that will motivate me? I don't know, but for now, I am motivated to play until the first dungeon (apparently Lvl. 35) and, for an MMO these days, that says a lot for me. Will update this as I go along.

Edit 1, 23th June 2015: PVP seems pretty well done. I have seen people saying that melee has an extreme disadvantage, but after playing a few matches, I have seen none of that. Of course, I am nowhere near experienced to really say for certain but it seems pretty fair to me for both melee and ranged, and PVP is kinda fun.

Edit 2, 29th June 2015: I played the game more, and rolled a new character. They all feel distinctively different which is certainly a good thing. I still recommend this game.

Edit 3, 07th July 2015: I think my final verdict on it is that it is certainly a good and fun way to pass time if you don't look for anything deep. Everyone else should stay away, because its very same-y.

reviewText:
Ok, so my time in this game was VERY short lived. I have played MMO's since before WoW was an idea. I may throw some more time into this game, but I highly doubt it.

First off, all classes are genderlocked. So no, you can not choose your gender. Honestly, not a big issue with me as I'm more about the gameplay and content. It was just a drawback from the standpoint I love customization and variety in my appearance, which once again, this game does practically does not have.

Second, story seems pretty generic. World is in trouble, gods need you, yadada. No biggy, it's hard to find an original premise for stories these days. But the world itself is pretty cool. GFX aren't the best of 2015, but it's a F2P....no complaints for not having billion dollar budget GFX.

The controls and camera are what cut my time short in this game honestly. I can deal with lack of variety, a medoicre story, crappy graphics...but holy crap...Q and E do not strafe and the camera has to be manually turned. Your A and D keys to not turn your character, but strafe instead. All turning requires the mouse and often times you turn the camera but your character will keep running in the direction you were originally running (AKA character doesn't turn with the camera). I spent more time trying to move and target enemies than actually fighting...I think the only other MMO I've played that had that kind of control/camera system MIGHT have been Lineage II, but even it wasn' this bad.

Combat, pretty generic point-and-click spam your rotation MMO. I personally like those kinda of combat system, but the camera issues really throw a wrench into this game...

All-in-all, I haven't dont anything outside of the little noob area (hell, didn't even finish that) but based on my experience here....this game is far from being any big award winners. Not the best, no the worst...but definitely not worth the time if you're looking for a good consistent MMO.

I may re-do this review later, but I feel like I will probably never devote enough time to do the game a fully unbiased review.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Echo of Soul looks like a typical Free to Play MMORPG with tab targeting.
Looks easy to level up, quests are easy fetch and kill types, Level cap is 70.  If you have not played other MMORPGs, this game would be a good starter game. Has a Login reward system.  Not much multiplayer content till level 70. Free riding mount and pets.

The female bodies look a little odd to me, their chest is too narrow while having a much bigger hip area.  You have a large selection of skin coloring, multiple shades of blue, purple, red black, grey. Able to enlarge head and adjust body height and leg height.  Has facial tatoos and odd eyes selection.  Has gender locked classes.

It has PVP, but other players say it is horrible.

Venture into solo dungeons and take on hordes of enemies as a one-man (or woman) army. Explore party dungeons with your friends and battle exhilarating bosses with Echo of Soul’s unique combat system, emphasizing cooperative healing. Without the need for a dedicated healer, every party member can get in on the action!
You can regenerate health while out of combat.

-  Five customizable classes: Warrior, Archer, Rogue, Guardian, and Sorceress.

-  Multiple specializations for each class, dramatically altering their style of play.

-  No dedicated healing classes, creating more fast-paced and strategic combat.

-  Soul System enables the collection of souls from fallen foes to activate buffs, enhance abilities, or craft useful items.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Echo of Soul or EOS was one of the realistic Fantasy MMO's of Aeria games, and i'll let you know, this is too sexy to be true.

Pros:True Free2Play material
5 Classes that after a level, you can be something more ( for example warrior can be Berserker or Protector as a class )
Amazing graphics and artstyle for its release date ( September 11, 2013 )
Plenty of options to configure ( Video/Audio/Mouse & Keyboard layouts/ UI/Font Chat Scaling  and plenty of more! )
Auto pathing mechanic
Combat style artstyle/effects are amazing
Soul system is nice ( it offers to activate buffs or enchant abilities or craft epic items )
Awesome community!
Cons:Tab targeting is not for this game. ( I would preffer it to have action attacks like TERA or WildStar )
PVP is not aswell the focused part of this game
Limited char appearence options
Gender locked Classes >.<
No healer class
Not many people play it nowdays ( at least that was my luck seeing empty enviroments )
Typical 2008 MMO structure base ( not much voice acting, not much alive enviroment, everything seem so robotic like.. )
Optional Comments
Also i heard that some people with win 10 ( any version ), have some problems running its launcher or overall the game itself. As a windows 10 Pro user, i haven't gotten this issue at all. If you do so, please report it ASAP to the Aeria Games to fix it up or find a specific solution for your problem!

End of Line
The game does offer a true Free2Play material which means is not p2w, but its mechanics , the way that it works towards us and the storyline of the game and aswell its MMO aspects, boring me alot and seem like the game could do it all by its own..also the starting area is not a starting point for someone that is hyped for a game to start off..my emotions are mixed after that..

But do try it if you happen to have an Aeria games account, or else i wouldn't bother much with it, but again i want you to try it out and tell me aswell your opinion.


Although this review is all my opinion, others may vary with different point of view.

reviewText:
I am a veteran wow player playing vanilla private servers on and off for 7 years and I just want to say as a elitist mmo ♥♥♥ that this is the ONLY anime mmo you will find with endgame.

PVP is fun, there are 2 bgs and some 5v5 arena (havent done arena yet). The bgs are really cool and this game is still relatively new so they might add another which I think they should consider.

I haven't done much PVE yet but I watched some videos of the raids and they seemed like really long fights that actually required tactics, to say the least I was impressed by the videos I saw. (looks like there is legitimate gear progression as well that makes the pve content last a long time).

I have played this for about 13 hours at the time of this post and I have to say it has enough unique elements to make it a little different than a few mmos as far as professions and the soul system. (and combat seeing as there is no dedicated healing class).

Kind of like gw2 meets fable meets wow but unlike gw2 it actually has a feeling of progression instead of running around having no idea what your doing. There is an npc in the main town that gives you a quest to go to a level appropriate zone if you outlevel the content you were previously on, which can happen if you run dungeons and do a pvp daily after level 15 that gives a level each day basically. (which I was impressed with).

I have yet to do a party dungeon but I am leveling a tank and I have done a few solo dungeons (I am only level 24) and they seemed to be pretty solid and I can start to see how the mechanics work and its really exciting.

The numbers aren't too big either which is what I like. The damage output is similar to burning crusade wow atleast from what it looks like. I don't think this game can mess up the system they have very easily so it feels like a good enough investment spending my time here.

Much better than other Anime Mmos seeing as Aura Kingdom's level grind is insane and doesn't seem to have endgame whats so ever and Mabinogi is out dated and theres no reason to log on besides troll free loot events.

I have been around, played a lot of anime mmo's off and on just as a troll for fun and this one impressed me enough to write a review and I haven't even played it that long.

iz pretty cool.

reviewText:
Echo of Soul is one of those games you pick up when you're bored and want to play some anime styled free2play MMO but have already played the well known games like Mabinogi, Maplestory, Aura Kingdom, Elsword, and the like. It's your typical, run of the mill tab target MMO that doesn't require much thinking. And for that it's great, but man the game does get boring rather quickly.

Graphics: They're good; not 10/10, but unless you're a big name developer your game isn't going to have 10/10 graphics anyway, and this is the case of Echo of Soul. Character models look alright, though I wish the archer elf model didn't have such huge ears. This is one of my gripes with MMOs anyway that feature elves; why must they always have huge pointy ears? I blame LOTR and other franchises, but that's neither here nor there. As for the game environment, it's alright. Standard MMO fare, nicely modeled but still a bit rough around the edges, but that's to be expected. I will give props to the user interface and the control system though. The UI is very intuitive and easy to understand while the control system is very familiar; plus, the drop system actually makes sense and doesn't act funky when dealing with multiple mobs (unlike Aion, which is incredibly finicky and bulky).

Gameplay: As I have said (and so have others), it's a tab-targeting system. Playing as an elf huntress was rather easy; just click and spam skills at enemies, no need to memorize rotation or worry about cooldown times; just click away. I confess though I am not at end game, so maybe this changes when you reach level 60. That said, gameplay is very, very, very basic at this point and I can see why some people might get turned off and not reach end game. It's just pick up quests from one area->kill the monsters/pick up drops->turn into respective NPC->repeat process. Heck, even the map layounts don't change much and are easy to memorize. It turns into one large area with four small areas connected to the side; complete all the side areas, move onto the next, and you're done. Combine that with the questing process and the combat system and you have yourself a game that is so brainless you can play it half asleep - hell, I've done it.

Sound: Nothing fancy; moving on. Music is pretty average for this game as well, but I wasn't expecting anything else.

Ultimately the game's averageness is its own undoing. Boring combat, repetitive quests and predictable area mapping makes for a painfully mediocre game. I can't think of a game that is just more there" than this. I also find it hard to recommend. One one hand
date: not recommending it is not being fair; the game isn't terrible
recommended: but recommending it would give it too much credit. Maybe the game is there to sate our hunger for average MMOs
hoursPlayed: but there are better MMOs out there. But if you played all those MMOs already
voteText: there is this."

reviewText:
I've been playing this game quite a lot during the closed beta and I have to say I had much fun with my friends. I came here looking for a fun Free-2-Play MMORPG, and I got what I wanted. I would give it a 90% rating in the MMO category. For my group of friends it was kind of a WoW/Lineage 2 revival. Easy to get into it, fun PvP and dungeons, and I especially like the game-design and art style (even though on the tech side the game is not The Witcher III, let's face it ^^ But my laptop could run it pretty smooth in high, it looks sharp).

Sure it's not revolutionary and it doesn't have a special feature that stands out, but it becomes more and more attractive and interesting as you play the game. It has all the features I was looking for, different types of PvP, a ton of dungeons to farm gear, cool mounts and pets (if you like lamas you'll love riding them in this game lol), nice crafting systems, a pretty extensive job system and the end-game content seems huge (even though I have done much myself after I hit level 60, I need a bit more time to look into it as I was having some fun in PvP for a while and put the dungeons/questing on the side).

It's pretty easy to get into it even for MMORPG beginners, the interface is user friendly, and I found the learning curve well done. I felt I actually needed some time to master some skills and to start feeling powerful, which is a good thing IMO (I don't like hen its too easy). I got crushed my first few times in PvP but now I actually do quite well without spending a single penny and without having amazing skills myself.

On the negative side, I would say that there is some grinding involved that can become a bit boring at some point. I don't mind farming personally, but I know some friend wanted to progress a bit faster. Yet, nothing crazy either, still in line with many other MMORPGs, especially those coming from Asia.

Regarding the debate P2W or not"
date: it didn't felt Pay-2Win to my eyes
recommended: especially in comparison to some other Free-2-Play MMOs. Sure there is a shop
hoursPlayed: but you can get most stuff via in-game drops
voteText: via the magic egg system (cool idea for free players)
helpfulPercent: or by buying in the auction house. I have some friends who spent some cash on the game to buy some mounts and costumes plus some boosts for leveling
votesHelpful: but in PvP we were on the same level. So all good from my point of view on that side. Might consider spending if I continue to play for a while
votesTotal: but I don't feel forced to do so...\n\nSo overall I really like the game and will continue to play for a while. It's perfect for casual MMO players but also interesting for experienced players. Found the game well balanced and not Pay-2-Win so far. A good example of what a F2P MMORPG should be!"

reviewText:
Ive played since day 1 OBT it was going okay until recently with pvp season 2 although it isnt a pvp based game.... however Aeria has stooped extremely low into the 'leech players for money' tactic that they allowed a instant lvl 35 boost for their new character, the warlock. In case you still decide to play level 35 can be achieved in an incredible short time. The economy has become completely broken by the cash shoppers like every other game where f2p is not f2p. Do not pvp in this game if you want your time wasted when a new seaon comes they completely wipe your gear... Anyone who puts money into this game (and tbh even playing it at this point...) is completely wasting their time. Do not fall for this scam...Do not fall for Aeria, they are a waste of what could be a reasonably good development crew.

Let's not fail to mention this either...

There have been multiple incidents where this have occured and not just with myself but many people who have played the game.

Aeria, at least for this game that I know of, uses a SEPERATE login server and game server.

Meaning whenever you login to the game of course you have to go through ANOTHER server so when the login server crashes you have 2 options...

1) Wait for the servers to be fixed then get on and be told that they will compensate everyone for the login servers being down... one of two things will happen here either you get ONE of these blessings: Edun's, Njord's, and (if the problem was that huge of an occurance) Levina's (+4 Atk 2hours, +4% Def 2hours, Double EXP and Gold for 24 hours <---- rare)

2) IF you are in game then you cannot log out which of course isn't that hard to do EXCEPT when Aeria is fixing their login servers SOMEHOW they screw up the game servers also leaving you to inevitable crash while they fix the problem.

After they have this problem occur they undergo a maintenance to fix" the issue i.e. after the "fix" is done you can't login because its still broken...

That's just trying to get in game and stay in game...

The P2W or might as well call it P2P...

Now I am completely free to play in the game yet I am still the best Stormguard in the game but... It does not stop people from judging people about their gems. Anyone who knows me in game immediately wants my help with dungeon DPS but when you go into a dungeon and have to tell 4 random morons talking about gems to shut it and watch the DPS meter only for a F2P to come out on top they get livid....EXTREMELY livid. So besides the P2W to just be complete BS for PvE the player base is rather saddening.

But PvE is where the chance to "win" stops lets go to PvP

At first everything was okay people were learning and figuring things out so you could fight and in that time gather gear to keep yourself balanced with them BUT the new players were matched against the "skilled" (P2W theres no skill in opening a wallet) players its like watching a gazelle try to befriend a lion. But... it managed to get remarkable worse..

As I stated earlier they released PvP Season 2 (Even the developer himself stated that it wasnt a pvp based game).

Before the occurance of Season 2 GM's stated that you should quickly use your pvp currency because they would be wiped. However
date: they FAILED to mention anything about a PVP GEAR WIPE. So many people F2P and P2W began grinding gear in the last few moments of the first season. Just to have it completely replaced with newer higher level gear.\n\nWell you might be thinking now
recommended:
"Why's he ♥♥♥♥♥ing about this? It means everyone is on fair ground."

No...no it doesn't allow me to explain.

( Keep in mind that all gem scalings are the same and that the next tier of gem only increase the item level that it can be slotted into.)

A gem in this case lets use an Onyx a gem that is slotted into a helmet in order to increase the CRIT ACC stat from the helm.

Before the math begins lets start with a helm that just has 100 Base Crit Acc a +1 Dull Onyx or Lucid Onyx would both apply this affect:

+1 Crit Acc + 4% Crit Acc (of the base stat so +4) coming out to an added +5

Now this isnt much but the items you would use in pvp have MUCH higher base stats and youre not going to be running around with anything lower than +5

Now if you use a +6 you get :

+6 +26% (of base stat)

If the item only has a 100 thats a messley 32 stat points big woop...

Lets kick it up to the P2W's +11 Lucid jewels (no one has a +12 jewel yet but i will supply the scaling for all jewels anyway)

+11 +91% (of base stat) <--- yea thats right 91% that doubles the 100 stats to 202 but as you increase in gear of course that +11 wont double it but 91% sure about does.

Now coming soon there will be a new gem the "Intermediate gem" the lucid is consider a low rank gem...

But what happens when the Intermediates come out? Gem wipe....you just spent several thousand of USD to have it thrown away wouldn't you feel smart.

I will leave this with a chart of gem scaling of +1 to max +12


+1        +1 +4%
+2        +2 +6%
+3        +3 +9%
+4        +4 +13%
+5        +5 +19%
+6        +6 +26%
+7        +7 +35%
+8        +8 +46%
+9        +9 +59%
+10      +10 +74%
+11      +11 +91%    <--- highest lucid obtained so far by date of review
+12      +12 +110%  <--- highest dull obtained

Note: Dull Gems are no able to be used in items of 64 item level or higher so you must swap to lucid.

Someone in +8 gear is able to 1 HIT someone in +5 or +6 and someone in +11's can one hit anyone in +9 or lower and devestate someone in +10

As I said the 100 base stat was a mere example main items have stats more that quadruple that of an item that would have any 100 base stat."

EOS is a new cutesy anime style MMORPG with the classic MMO elements but a slight difference. You can relate it to WoW in terms of combat(for some part), nothing is seemingly new for such a new MMO, I will say its very well done for what it is. My long review, I hope this helps any one on edge about playing or not. Also consider it a mini basic things to know of the game.

Cash shop?
Yes. P2W? I wouldn't say yes or no it this. Everything in game can be purchased with gold through the market from other players, some cash shop items through the magic egg system"

PvP?

win or lose. I cannot say for that you are guarenteed rewards in arena with a lose though as I have yet to do that. Its a lot of fun but you may also find yourself wanting to bash your head off the wall at some of the players.

Guild Battles?
Yes! Open world guild pvp makes it a bit harder if you are lower level and new to the game. However avoiding a hostile guild is best until you are familiar and comfortable with the game and your class.
Guilds can compete in Valhalaa
column18:
where guilds will compete to kill a daily spawn boss for amazing rewards that will benefit your guild.

Dungeons?

found in lamps) or reset one of your uses with 1 ticket. You will get 30 gold per dungeon I believe. 10gish per boss. Its great for earning gold and then you can afford to upgrade gems or buy cool things this way!

Raids?
Coming Soon~

reviewText: I downloaded this game as soon as it became available on steam because I thought it looked interesting and I wanted to play a new mmo rpg. I didnt expect to like the game as much as I do, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fantastic free to play mmo rpg. There is so much to do once you hit 60 (max level) and it continues to be a very enjoyable game. Also, there is absolutely no pay to win aspect which is fantastic seeing as its a F2P RPG. If you can get past the fact that there is gender locking (I know, its 2015 and gender locking shouldn't be a thing in RPG MMOs anymore) it is a very fun game to play. Updates every few weeks to keep the game interesting and I hope they continue to grow and improve the game. Dont get me wrong, there are a number of faults with this game but nothing to make you steer clear of atleast giving this game a try for yourself. Gender Locking is a problem, but they make up for it with decent customization. Balance between classes is a bit off, but you can make up for it with skill. PvP and Dungeons are a ton of fun especially if you are spamming them with guildies/friends. All in all good F2P RPG.

reviewText:
Tried this game today. the graphics are nice and from what I could see the game play was decent. That's as far as I got.

Right away I notice my FPS was capped at 60, no problem there's a setting that allows you to turn of the limitations. Then I noticed every few seconds my frames would drop from 150+ to the teens and start climbing again. so I started turning down settings. After reaching minimum setting on everything I decided to uninstall.

Steady fps is a must and I can not play a game where my fps is reset to almost nothing every few seconds. I do not run top end gaming rig but an Intel i7 4790k, nVidia GTX 770 and 16 gigs of ram should be able to run a Free to Play game at max settings with 0 fps issues.

I had high hopes for this game, too bad unsteady fps causing a stuttering effect had to ruin it.

reviewText: Now let's start like this, it's a decent MMO if you are looking for classics. The only problem it has is that sometimes can be glitchy, in some rare occasions which isn't that much of a problem to be honest, but it's nothing new. It's the most 'Typical' classic MMO with the rule of grinding quests and simple PVP mechanics. I like the souls system in the game, but that's the only thing that interested me in playing, but then compare the game to all other games that just recently came out or are about to go free to play like Archeage, Black Desert or Albion online, I feel these will be the games worth playing when they go free to play, Archeage has an amazing housing systme, Black Desert will have astonishing graphics and fighting mechanics and then Albion will have a very interested look at MMOs from multiple perspectives, but then when you look at EOS, It's just another MMO like any other. 5/10

reviewText:
As a general summary of this game, the whole things is as generic as a generic MMORPG can be. Generic evil entity wants generic fantasy world to end, and generic hero player starts the game while generic war ensues with generic guards fighting generic red demon monsters. Look I'm going to break it down really to just the pro's and con's.

Pros:

Cons:

reviewText:
This game made me bittersweet, but I will not reccomend it to other players.

Simply because. It's a simple go here and get this MMO.

I'll explain why It made me bittersweet.

I like pretty games. I liked the outfits, the graphics were good.
I even liked the Soul part of the game. It was fairly interesting.

But...The quests were the same. I did a dungeon by myself. There was no need to play with other players.

The reason it made me bittersweet is because I did like the game concept. The battling was nice, but the battling threw me off because I couldn't move much. ( I was an archer.) The sidestep was literally pointless, I don't know why they bothered to put it there, but I did like the Soul stuff. How you would have wings of color on your back. I thought it was cool.

So basically

Pro: Good graphics. Interesting concept with souls.  Pantie shots. >->
The battling was decent. The story was okay. Not the best. Music was decent too.


Cons: Sidestepping was pointless. ( I like to move when I'm battling.)
The quests were go here and get that. Basically, gathering and killing things.


Even though it looks like the pros outweight the cons. The quests are the MAIN part of the game and for that. It sufferered a thumbs down for me.  Sorry Aeria. Not your best game, but it's decent if you're looking for a simple MMO.

reviewText:
This game is great... I can't see where the negative reviews are coming from. The visuals are stunning, cute female characters, combat is fun and teamwork is involved to make the most out of party experience... this is one of the finest modern MMOs I have played. The game is free and everything is in real time. None of that FFXIII BS.

If you decide to play the first sequence of quests (which I'd agree are boring, fetch questing and generic) it would take approximately 4 hours and I'd recommend trying to go through it if only for the tutorials. When you reach the main city Ignea, you will be able to access Battlefield merchants and daily rewards which is great. It's like a MOBA within the RPG. Its a lot of fun especially with friends.

If you are offered an opportunity to join a guild, join up. Guild members are among the most helpful players around and will even offer newer players with commitment free items and will take time from their own day to help you with dungeons, resources, etc.

The REAL fun starts when you reach 60. You will have access to a slew of solo dungeons, dailies and a seperate lv60 Battlefield and Arena. Some of the daily quests are a bit of grind, but the rewards you reap can get you Magic Eggs which is sort of like f2p premium currency... using the eggs you can get Dungeon Tickets or Magic Lamps which will give you untradeable variants of premium AP bought items.

This game is NOT play to win and most of the items in the store are cosmetics. There is an insta-lv60 kit for sale but that is reserved to players who ALREADY put work into leveling at least one other account to 60 first!

So my advice is not to quit within the first 4 hours... once you reach Ignea and run the battlefield 'til 60, you will end up having so much fun. I actually stuck with the main quest line and did all the side quests in between and it took me about 40-50 hours, but then I decided to do dungeons and pvp instead and that has granted me over 100 hours of gameplay to boot.

Addendum: Huntresses and Duelists are OP, but instead of complaining about balance in classes, why not create one for yourself? Its what you make of it and what is tailored to your playstyle. I like the Huntress a LOT for PVP but started off as an assassin rogue which I personally find great for PvE.

reviewText: Great game, with the World Of Warcraft based GUI and average graphics. However what the game lacks in is what most games in whole lack in, that's captivating the player with the starter quests of the game and throwing all you can to that point of the game, leaving the rest of the main quests not exciting like saving women from beasts or searching the shops for a cute plushie. I highly recommend this TPS MMORPG game to patient people. People who can stand killing the same things over and over again, With a slight change in loot collected or loot needed to complete the quest. In the game there are a series of bugs and glitches and simple mistakes that take time out of your gameplay to abondon the quest and re-do it. For example you deleting a quest item on accedent and having to abandon it and collectit back, Although this is a player based thing, we shouldn't be aloud to delete or sell any quest item in the game, also if a bug happens during the main quest when you're half way through it... Believe me i speak from experience that it is plain annoying that you needing to spend an extra twenty muinets going through the quest and completing it again with you knowing how you could've completed the game half an hour prier.\n\nStill, i'm not hating on the game for what it is. The game is a average game with a huge helping community, without the mass spam of ingame payments.

reviewText:
If you need a secondary game to pass time with, this would be it. I know I have tons of hours on this game, but truth be told it's because I love the friends I've made on it. Pvp before level 60 is more fun than when you hit 60 because it's closer to being balanced than after you reach cap level. The quests are a bit repetitive, but if you do them with a friend or two, it can be fun. I've made numerous characters and they all have their pros and cons.

As for the game, itself...it's okay. Not excellent, but not awful. It depends on what you're looking for.

As for the pay to win aspect that many are curious about...before you hit level 60, I'd say no...it's not pay to win at all. You can progress the entire time without spending a dime. The dull gems come easy and will be free to enhance for your gear. As for when you hit 60? It may tend to feel a little pay to win-ish only because you will need premium items to help you enhance your gems as you will no longer be able to use dulls. I was disappointed when they released antlers/santa hat that offered extra stats for pvp, being that the majority of the people using them were those that were already pretty much the strongest on the game, but at the end of it all...it's no different than the pet whistles you get if you purchase the correct sets of pets in game.

Do I recommend it? Sure...but I'm also not blind to it's faults.

Battlefield needs a serious overhaul, more maps, and either they separate those ubers from us regulars in game or they need to fix it so you can't form premade teams. Why? Because it's no fun playing against a team of premium barbarians. When you end up with scores like 10k-1k, something is definitely wrong. People have taken to staying in base and waiting for the round to be over because they can't cap towers/grab resources or defend themselves.

The dungeons aren't so bad, but it would be nice for it to drop gear pieces of the classes in the party running them. It's so frustrating to waste heals (expensive once you hit 60) to run a dungeon just to end up with drops that no one can use. One of the biggest reasons, I mostly play pvp even though that is a headache in itself.


I'd give the game a 7/10

reviewText:
I read so many bad reviews about the game either from the press or just here so it took me so long to hop on and try it.
I started playing out of boredom when heavensward didn't seem to cut it for me and i'm so happy i did because i'm glad.

This game takes every single good mmorpg system and just delivers it in a very polished and tweaked maner. Small details here and there. It is very standard and very expected. Quest hubs, typical class's with dual specs, instances, etc etc. The hole thing is very common but yet very well done and tweaked to be very enjoyable.

I really like this game and so far i didn't find any cons to it yet. I will maybe find some bad things to say about it along the way or at max level, but so far it is the most enjoyable mmo i played since a very long time and i like it.

Nothing fancy like wow killer, or super inovation for the sake of inovation, just a very solid mmorpg like they used to make back in the days with some tweaks and flavor that makes the difference.

reviewText:
Ok. I don't write reviews here but it is kind of unfair to have mixed review for this game, for it one of the better F2P MMORPGs you can find out there.

Story might be boring, graphics might look outdated but if you pass through these, you will find an MMO which is quite fun to play with interesting classes and solid character improvement. It might be bad for some but I find it great that leveling quite easy (you can reach max level in around 40 hours) and there is a lot of end game content to keep you occupied. If you are into competitive game, you can go PVP and if you are into cooperative game you can go for dungeons and epic raids.

reviewText: This is an okay game, not great though. I didn't have to play it long to see that it wants your money, and is buggy. I'm sure the bugs will be cleared up at some point, but I'm being dropped out of the game every ten minutes. I tried other servers to see if the dropping was just the server I was on, but it was all of them. I did like that it gave you mounts, but I wish that we are able to fight on them, or even gather plants or items from them instead of just the 'faster' transport that they allow.  The hot keys are difficult to use and changing them doesn't help much. I also wish that you didn't have to click the target (Even pressing tab doesn't help much) to be able to attack rather than just face and be able to attack.\n\nThe story is okay for as far as I am able to get (again, keep getting kicked off the game for no reason) so that is a point in their favor.  If you like rpg's then I say try it, it is okay and you'll never know if you'll like it until you try it.

reviewText: Played my fair share of these types of games and while it has some things I like, it's pretty bland. I came to this game out of pure boredom. Let us just say, it didn't fix my problem. Classes are gender/race locked, visuals are pretty horrid. While the character models seem decent, the terrain/environment is ugly as ♥♥♥♥. Leveling is generic and boring, though I don't expect any more from an mmo tbh. Quest leveling is hard to escape. You unlock PvP at level 10. You can level via battlegrounds if you like, though it isn't well balanced atm and you're GOING to get wrecked, especially as a Rogue. So far my PvP experience has been rough, with players constantly shouting to do things a certain way and to gtfo". None of this being aimed at me as far as I know but honestly the PvP is pretty easy to grasp. From the modes i've played it's just capping ♥♥♥♥. reviewText:
Played before it was on steam.(ALOT)

This Game in a Nutshell.

Good Game
♥♥♥♥♥♥ Graphics
♥♥♥♥♥♥ Fps 52-62 on a high end rig which is atrocious considering the sub par engine and the graphics in general.
But the Gameplay is really fluent and just leaves so many opportunities to personalize skills / movement to your advantage.
50% of the Skills can be cancelled which exponentially increases your DPS in general but  especially in pvp.
PVE Gameplay is decent , story is nothing new  not good ... but not bad either.

But the thing when it comes to pvp is the same as in every other , cashers .... cashers everywhere ...
BUT FEAR NOT , i haven't paid 0.00€ in my playtime of 970hours (raptr approves) and i ♥♥♥♥ on cashers about 80% of the time.
The thing is when you can pay for something , you can usually craft it which requires more effort but will be rewarded.
Or you trade good drops against the reallife currency , long words short story = play the game and you will be rewarded.
Even if they have 10% more damage you can still outsmart them when it comes to mechanics.
And if you think the game will be boring after 60 , ye that might be partially true BUT who said you have to stick with 1 character?
Level others , change servers , make new accounts . That isn't a big deal and is usually no problem unless you don't enjoy the game.

I personally enjoy the game , and of course i do recommend this game to everyone who enjoys MMORPGS and isn't afraid to put an enormous amount of time into it.

Aye , forgot 1 thing.
That's what happens when you fight a casher with full f2p equip and win.

Normal Miss Normal , Crit Crit Crit Crit Crit Crit (RIP) HACKING ♥♥♥♥♥♥"
"

reviewText:
If you like playing games like Neverwinter, Terra, WoW or Guild wars, then this game is good for you to have some variation in your games or just to play someting new.
The combat system is very convenient and very simular to neverwinter, WoW and GW.
Key features of the game which I like are:
-PvP and PvE with lots of dungeons.
-Crafting and professions.
-Socketing system.
-Choosing different skill pathways.

Things I like less but are imo not that important:
-Lack of character customization.
- No real healers: only tank, dps or debuffing.
I haven't seen anything like pay to win advantages, more paying for unique outfits or pets.

Overal, this game is above average for a free to play mmorpg and I can definitely recommend this game for players who want something new or something for variation.

reviewText: Echo of Soul is a very beautiful and charming mmorpg. The story is well written, rich, and offers both humor and an intense fantasy feel. Characters and landscapes alike are total eye candy, detailed and full of depth. Interface and gameplay wise, EoS shares basic features with other mmorpgs, but has its own unique style. Character movements are smooth and well adjusted, and the GUI is very pleasant and easy to navigate. As a diehard fantasy rpg fan, I highly recommend Echo of Soul to other likeminded.

reviewText:
First thing first: i couldnt play the steam version. The servers would DC me as soon as i try to log on. I had to download it from the aeria-website~

EOS feels like a MMO that should have been released in 2004 or so. Everything feels kind of sluggish and slow. The char movement... it looks like you are trying to run but something is holding you back, so it takes kind of long to get to the next enemy (i catch myself hitting shift" all the time).

Questing is the same old: Talk to person "A" -> report to person "B" -> person "B" needs you to kill monster "X" etc.

Content is lacking right from the beginning~

5 classes which are gender locked (why?):
-Warrior (male)
-Rogue (male)
-Archer (female)
-Guardian (female)
-Sorceress (female)

Each class has 2 specializations which are fairly expectable:
-Berserker (DD-Warrior)
-Protector (Tank-Warrior)
-Huntress (DD-Archer)
-Bard (Support-Archer)
-Duelist (DD-Rogue)
-Assassin (DD-Rogue with poison?)
-Stormguard (AoE-Guardian)
-Earthguard (2nd-Tank/Support-Guardian)
-Firemage (DD-Sorceress)
-Frostmage (CC-Sorceress)

Each class uses one specific type of weapon that you get now and then through quests (so there is no need to buy them).

Its kind of a cheap version of TERA. I hoped this game would be as fun as Rappelz back in the day T_T"

reviewText:
To add some context first for my opinion:
I played or tried many MMORPGs, few of them for a bit longer time. However, all of them grew boring rather quickly, so I do not particularly like MMOs, mainly because of the slow progression / grind and the very static worlds, as there can be no big changes resulting from your actions, as the next player must have the same content available.
I am also not interested in PvP, so I cannot say anything about this here.
The playtime recorded by Steam might be rather low, when you read this, but I played the game for a longer time before, as it was released on Aeria Games' own website some time before the Steam release.

GAMEPLAY
I gave Echo of Soul a fair try, as with those other games. In the end I must say, that I am positively surprised.
The PvE balancing and Quest goals are done in a way, that does not halt your progression through the game. The flow feels like Diablo 3 i.e. you keep moving through the game without being forced to stop and grind in one area.
They also use the phasing system that games like World of Warcraft used, so that the world around you actually is able to change in response to completed quests. For example, early in the game you arrive at a town, which is on fire and overrun by enemies. After you save it, the world changes and the town is normal again, functioning as a regular in-game hub with merchants and players etc.

VISUALS
The graphics and design are nothing new or spectacular, but EOS does look very nice and inviting. In addition it has it's own charm, as you can create quite extravagant characters. You have a variety of unusual hair and skin colors to select from and the size slider has a big range as well. It is not as expansive as some other games, but definitely good enough to not be limiting.

CASH SHOP
I read in other reviews, that the game feels Pay to Win for them. Looking at the items available on the Cash Shop, I can understand this notion, as some items seem quite powerful. But in all the time I played, I never actually felt compelled to buy anything there, as the game's balancing does not feel, like I would really need any of them. The only thing that really is of interest, are the extended bags, as there is quite some loot to carry around after some time of play. Even the standard mounts, of which you get one very early in the game, are sufficient, so you do not need to buy a better one.

TECHNICAL
I did not encounter any serious lag or other technical issues. The game ran smooth and stable for me. There was only some lags on the release day, a couple of weeks ago, but that is completely normal for an MMO. I read that some people's Antivirus software is giving warnings, but this also happens with many online games, as the Anti-Hack tools can be seen as false positives by those Antivirus tools. I personally did not have this issue.

BOTTOM LINE
Echo of Soul is nothing new or extravagant. It is competent, solid and the actual gameplay is done in a way that it is entertaining without any grind. It might not be made for the hardcore players or those that want a great PvP game. But if you are looking for a good time in PvE, Echo of Soul is definitely worth a try.

TL;DR:
Overall I can recommend it. Good PvE, no grind, Cash Shop can be ignored without problems. No lags or other technical issues that I saw.

reviewText:
just wanted to share my opinion on this game

i´ve played wow for over 9 years, was a couple of years in a progress hardcore raid guild and played in 2v2, 3v3 and 5v5 with a rating over 2k easily..in my wow years i paused often and played a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of other mmorpgs and to tell you the truth..this is the first after wow that i think i can spent a couple of years with.

the graphics is a typical anime-esquee style but not as cheesy as others and after a couple of minutes you get used to it if you never played games with this kind of graphics

it has typical runes and jewel stuff to upgrade your equip and you can awaken your items to shot the hidden potential" which are similar to random enchantments i guess

the quest system is symple and easy to understand with nice direction and distance tips and changing markings on the map when the monster you need to hunt moves

but the most awesome thing about this is the actual combat..as a wow "veteran" i loved the challenge in pve
recommended:
moving and calculating everything to get the most dps or whatever and this game is one of the few that has this kind of combat system

another big plus is the soul system which is something fresh and new for me: monsters drop chaos souls which can be purified to one of four different "soulds" and those souls act as special skills that ingrease stats for a short period of time and are pretty awesome to kill bosses in solo dungeons (havent tried 5 man dungeons yet) and i must admit that the difficulty of those solo dungeons arent to be underestimated and are really fun and challenging

overall i have to say that this game is ♥♥♥♥ING AWESOME and you should try it..i dont know about the p2w part because im not 60 yet and tested the end content but you can get mystical eggs or something which is similar to ap ( the real money currency) but anyway...it is a great mmo and im probably going to play it for a long time and you should test for yourself if you like it or not :D"

reviewText:
Echo of Soul takes the classic RPG formula and gives you all the options you would need. Leveling is relatively linear, though you can decide to do so through PVE or PVP, with everything pushing you to end game. You pick up a mount early on and quest drops drop pretty often, which is pretty nice.

There are a few negatives, there's a cash shop quest early on, though it's skippable and after that you don't really hear from it again. Also the classes are gender-locked which isn't a huge deal breaker for me, but I know it can be for some people.

TL;DR The game is not reinventing the wheel, but what it does it actually does quite well, so definitely worth to give it a try.
voteText: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I played during the CBT and now in OBT - up to lvl 60 with war protector - Lxsd on EU-servers

EoS is very polished for a F2P, graphics aren't astonishing but pretty, classes and skills offer a variety of gameplay and builds very satisfying. The UI is very user friendly and compiles a lot of cool features (e.g. inventory manager). Early levels a bit boring, the game really starts around lvl 50. The progression until then is a grinding & quests or PVP battlegrounds.

The soul and crafting systems are also interesting and featuring a lot of cooperation aspects (coop refining, complementary jobs). They are maybe too simple and straightforward (small amount of materials, recipes), do not offer a lot of different specs but at least they give useful items.

The cash-shop offers a lot of stuff, like mounts, vanity items and boosters. The costumes aren't coming with any statistic, only vanity. Some boosters are available (4% atk/def, 30% pvp marks, +100% xp/gold) - the rest is mostly convenience such as character slots, bags, and other crap. Most items are tradable and available for gold at the AH, so people who don't spend can still access almost every item item that could break the balance - EoS honeypots you to spend some cash but is not P2W imo - i bought a founder's pack to access CBT and get the limited edition mount but always got cash items vs. gold at the AH since then, including safegards.

Pros:

- Pretty graphics (except for these horrible ground textures :s), interesting lore
- Variety of classes & gameplays
- Good UI - user friendly
- Interesting Crafting system + coop soul refining
- All cash items tradable, therefore the AH is full of cheap cash items for Gold
- Guild wars and other coop features
- High level content & raids
- bad ♥♥♥ sword for warriors

Cons:

- Instanced areas and channels (i'm not a fan of this system)
- Gender-locked classes
- Lack of low level coop dungeons (35/50 - adding a lvl 20 coop dungeon would be cool)
- Polished but generic game
- Lack of pvp battlegrounds


It's free and it's honestly pretty packed for a F2P, there is far worst crap on Steam atm - definitely worth the try.

reviewText:
Echo of Souls is a beatifull made MMORPG with alot to describe but ill only do a short
review now.
It has good graphics, an interesting storyline, multiple well designed pre-set Classes and
alot of Quests for the player to do if you believ the info over 1000+ quests for you to enjoy :3
The Community is how it first seems based on about 3 languages english, german and afew french players
but still friendly and not too mature.
You have 60 lvl to climb and making your Soulkeeper look awesome on the go with many different types
of armor and weapons.
The PvP is sadly nothing for beginners since the matchmaking puts lvl 15 players against lvl 40+ but the game balances that with a little passive that gives players under a specific lvl a hp and attack boost so they can actually fight back.
Since the publisher is Aeria games the cash shop is sadly a bit expensive as seen on other aeria games but its not needed
since theres no real dmg buff or anything like that it is mostly just outfits and pets even though you get a free
1week pet at the beginning with a mail. This has been the review and i hope it helped but you guys
should make yourself an experience in the game itself so i recommend it to others who love putting in time to
create a strong character designed to become a grea Soulkeeper!
